name: Develop guidelines
detail: Core regulatory framework for AI governance

name: Ban some uses of or types of AI
detail: Restrict specific harmful AI applications

name: Provide learning opportunities for teachers / students / school leaders
detail: Educational support for stakeholders

name: Provide non-AI alternatives to the technology to do the same tasks.
detail: Ensure access without AI dependency

name: Change how the AI / tool is used
Invest in a tool / person e.g., to collect / explore data, create policy, implement changes, etc.
Require tool providers to provide evidence of how effective or ‘ethical’ they are
Go back to the status quo
Involve stakeholders in decision making around the problem or/and use of AI
Introduce rewards / penalties for good / bad use of AI
Establish an oversight body or system to monitor the impacts of AI
Share examples of good / problematic practice
Advocate for change to a relevant stakeholder/s
Seek school sponsorship / partnership with an external partner (e.g., EdTech company).
Create a tool to support users monitor the energy and water consumption of their AI use.
Require annual reporting and ongoing monitoring of emerging impacts of tools

detail: System to identify learners needing support

name: Workload
detail: Reducing teacher burden equitably

detail: Providing meaningful feedback to all students

detail: AI for enrichment and class streaming

name: Digital skills
detail: Building digital literacy for all

name: Engagement
detail: Tracking learning engagement authentically

name: Careers guidance
detail: AI career guidance tool

name: Meeting accessibility obliations
detail: Your school is legally required to provide accessible materials for all students...

name: Personalised learning
detail: Adaptive Learning Platforms: This AI-driven platform personalizes instruction for each student...

name: Wellbeing
detail: AI-Driven Counseling Support: A new AI system helps school counselors identify students in need of emotional support early...

name: Privacy breach
detail: Unauthorized access to student data

name: Does everyone in the school know how the AI system works?
detail: System transparency question

name: Can the AI system do what the EdTech company says it can?
detail: System capability verification

name: Pandemic
detail: Global health crisis affecting education

name: Who is accountable for performance
detail: Are humans involved in assessing performance

name: AI contested
detail: If a student/teacher disagrees with the outcome that an AI provides, what can they do in your school?

name: Wider-impacts
detail: What impacts might using this AI system have on other stakeholders? (E.g., parents, teachers, school leaders, wider community)

name: long-range impacts
detail: Imagine the system has been in place for longer than 5 years: Will the system have improved? Who will benefit from those improvements? Who "owns" the knowledge that led to those improvements? Will how the system is used have changed? Will human expertise and agency be retained? What impact will using the AI system have on longer term issues?

name: who cares
detail: Does the system tackle an issue or problem everyone thinks is important? If not, how has this happened?

name: who can access the system
detail: According to the latest Australian Digital Inclusion Index (ADII), almost a quarter of Australians are digitally excluded – meaning they don’t have access to essential technology.

name: energy-use
detail: Did you know: a ChatGPT request uses roughly 10 times a Google search query; and cooling data centres for AI uses water, with increased demand.

name: intergenerational-issues
detail: Intergenerational fairness describes issues relating to how burdens and benefits impact different generations, including long-range harms for present-day decisions.

name: fairness
detail: Imagine that AI is being used to solve a long-standing fairness issue in your school. How might this change how you think about the use of AI in your scenario?

name: pedagogic calcification
detail: stagnation

name: poor use
detail: poor use
